div.head: THE MONEY CRISIS.
div.p: "When we read the reports of the financial situation in America, we are reminded of the picturesque account which Lord Cromer gave as the other day of the habits of the people of Egypt," says the "Westminster Gazette" Nov. 5). "These people, it seems, have so little faith in banks and credit institutions that they cannot be induced to part with their gold when they have once got it into their possession. A vast deal of money. goes into Egypt which never comes out in; how mach, we may judge from the fact that during the last four years the imports: of gold have been thirteen millions more than the exports.

"What becomes of this vast quantity of coin ! A great deal, Lord Cramer tells us, is manufactured into jewelry. It is estimated that last year between one and half and two millions was disposed of in this way alone. The rest is hoarded. Lord Cromer tells us that a little while ago he heard of an Egyptian gentleman who died leaving a fortune of £80,000, the whole of which was found in his cellars. Then, again, he heard of a substantial yeoman who bought a property for £25,000. Half an hoar after the contract was signed he appeared with a train of donkeys bearing on their backs the money, which bad been buried in his garden.

"The European is at first tempted to cry out at the extreme folly of these simple people who deprive themselves of income in order to secure their capital. But he too, perhaps, when he considers the dismal tale of the stock and share lists and counts up his capital losses on money securely invested in high-class securities, say, four years ago, may say to himself on further reflection that these people have after all not proved so very foolish. - 'The argument is not to be pressed too far, or prudent husbands and fathers of families may find them selves beset by wives and daughters imploring them, in the name of thrift, the convert their surplus gold into articles of stable value which adorn the person instead of throwing it down the gulf of depreciating securities.

"But it isa very thin line which divides the civilised man from the primitive, and the present mood of the American man is to stick to his gold and keep it in cellars and back gardens, now that he has happily rescued it from the banks and the millionaires. Hence the extreme disorganization of the currency in America, and the frantic pull on the limited supply of European gold which compelled the Directors of the Bank of England yesterday (Nov. 4) to protect their position by raising the Bank rate to 6 per cent., with, possibly, a further rise to follow.

"The fact faces us that no possible accumulation of gold could avail us in presence ot anything like a general breakdown of the the credit system. Modern industry and commerce refuse to be controlled by the output of the gold mines of the world, however much it may be influenced by the fluctuations in prices which follow from a shortage or excess of the gold supply.

"The panic in America, which has sent people running to the banks for their gold, is due simply to the fact that depositors have lost faith in the honesty or discretion (or both) of certain men and groups of men who are temporarily masters of their credit. At this point the remedies are twofold. There is, first, the temporary remedy to be applied by the Government and the leading financiers in concert to restore cash payment or payment in notes, which are the equivalent of cash; and there is, secondly, the permanent remedy, in which also the Government must take a hand, of saving the public and the industry of the country from the wild gambling and dishonest dealing which, if it continued, would rot the whole fabric of trade and credit.

"President Roosevelt is trying to apply both remedies simultaneously. Trade and industry in America, like industry a few years ago in South Africa, are temporarily on a basis of unreal speculative values, which must gradually be brought down to hard fact, It will take time, and it will be accompanied by temporary hardship to many people and interests, but the American people have shown more than once that they are capable of conducting this operation with great thoroughness, and we have much belief in their capacity to do if again,"

div.head: Red Sea Malis.
div.p: Our Suez correspondent writes :—Although in September last the negotiations between the Italian Government, and the Florio-Ra- battino Company respecting a new monthly * mail service between Italy and Red. Sea ports fell through, they have apparently now come to some understanding in spite of the strong opposition of the Italian Colony of Erithrea, and a Rubattind steamer is intended to sal! 'from Suez on the 9th December next, for Port Sudan, Jeddah, Hodeidah, Massawah, Aden and Djibouti. The Colony at Eritrea have protested owing to the delay of the mvils, in the event the mail steamer calls at intermediate ports.

div.head: Merohant Seamen's Hoffte
div.p: During the summer months there has been a continuous demand by seamen for tempor ary lodging. The Home is at present full up, and it is to be regretted that frequently, owing to all available sleeping room being occupied, many have to seek accommodation outside the protection 'of the Home and the quay beundaries. It is apparent that in this respect, the resources of the Home are ina- dequate to the ordinary requirements of the port, apart from the necessity of providing for batches of men received under excep- tional circumstances, as was the case this summer, when aecommodation was requested for the creo the stranded S.S. "Olivemoor," who were put up at the Home for 22 days,

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: The Lilliputian troupe are not so good as their predecessors of last year, but they are delightful nevertheless. So far I bave heard "Lucia di Lammermoor" and the "Geisha". Lucia was characteristic, the children out- Heroded Herod or rather, out Sara-d Sara. All the tragic gestures, glances, intonations appeared, heightened by a delicate tonch' of exaggeration-they were playing at being Lucia, Sir Edgardo, Lord Enrico Sir Edgardo was especially pleasing ; he had a way of his own in discarding cloak and hat, drawing or sheathing his sword. Lord Enrico was but little behind him. Their self consciousnes was absorbing, + quite different from the fatuity of the tenor, baritone, and soprano who think of their high notes, their phrasing, the audience. These boys and girls probably thought of their nice clothes, and the fun of acting a real tragedy on a real stage.

The ''Geisha" was charming as a whole, the ' music was taken in the Italian style, drawn out, slower, heightening such effgets as it has, and the fan was spontaneous and telling. The youth who represented Wung Hi is precocious beyond his years and should make a comedian one day. The Geisha herself, and Madame L'Interpréte are also older, and more formed, and can well be compared with grown-up per- formers. Mimosa San's rendering of the Gold Fish song was charming in itself and not merely for its environment.

As to these performances, qua performances, the individual singing of the younger mem- bers is admirable, they know their parts, and have pretty voices, well enough trained. The chorus is apt to go out of tune at moments. The orchestra play far too loud as a rule, and are too hard on the voices. It was the same, last time, when the director of the troupe was atthe piano, he did not seem to allow for theage of his singers.

Mile Dora Theor who took Lucia, and the Geisha is in a sense a finished singer — more 30 almost than Mile Lidia Levi of last year, but without the same perfection of voice : Mile Lidia Levi bad a singularly beautiful voice, acertain purity and appeal in that it attracted and held the attention, one could not forget it.

At any rate, if Mile Lidia Levi, Mlle Theor is well worth hearing for her singing alone. The rest are delightful because they have pleasant childrens' voices, and their whole performance gives a distinct impression in contrast to opera in general by trained opera singers, it is a novelty, and a most charming novelty at that.

div.head:
A COTTON CRISIS.
DANGER OF A STRIKE.
div.p: London, Saturday.

At a meeting of the master cotton-spinners held yesterday at Manchester, it was decided to refuse the applications of the spinners of fine counts at Oldham for an increase of wages, Strike notices expire at seventy mills next week. 'T'welve thousand work people are affected.

div.head: THE CULTIVATION OF COTTON.
div.p: Herr Koffler, president of this year's Inter- national Cotton Congress at Vienna, was interviewed at Manchester last week on his return from America. He said the deputation of European spinners to the United States had been impressed by the fact that the American cottonfields could be made to yield much more than they yielded to-day. It was very important also that a knowledge of various grades of cotton should be spread among American cotton farmers who were unaware of the reasons why spinners pre- ferred one staple over another. The method of growing and handling cotton could be very greatly improved, and the spinners of Europe would have to give an object-lesson by them- selves forming a company, buying a fair-sized plantation in America, managing it on the best lines, and in this way putting to the test the practical suggestions that have recently been made. The American farmers, he said, were better organised than was thought, but they could not yet command their members on the question of the prices to be demanded for cotton or on the question of holding baek the eotton from the market.

div.head:
THE END OF RAMADAN.
CELEBRATION IN LONDON.
div.p: The end of the fast of Ramadan was cele- brated by Mohamedans in London at the Hol- born Restaurant last Thursday week.

There was nothing in the surroundings to make the event impressive says the '"I'ribune'". The service was held in a dark upper room of the Holborn Restaurant. Servants were sweeping the approaches to the apartments, and the lights were out. There was no instrumental music ; there were no ritualistic appointments. Yet, in spite, of all this, the short service in a dining-room appealed with powerful force to the imagination of those with even an elementary knowledge of the religions of the world.

'There is but one God, and Mahomet is his prophet !" And here, in the heart of Christian London, half a hundred good Moslems assem- bled at the appointed time, turned their faces to Mecca, and bowed the head in adoration of Allah and his preacher.

An Imam was chosen for the occasion to say the "Id-ul-Fitr" prayer. He was Mr. H. M. Shairini, the secretary of the Pan-Islamic Society. He took off his boots and assumed his turban. In the same way all the worship- pers removed their boots and assumed either fez or turban. A Mohamedan must cover his head at prayer, and that covering must have no brim, otherwise the genuflection to the ground would be impede. There were Moslems presént from Turkey, Arabia, Egypt, India, Bormah, Afghanistan, and South Africa.

The Imam said his prayers, providing the welcome sign that the thirty days' fast was over. The worshippers bowed their heads to the ground as he uttered the phrases in praise of Allah and the Prophet. Late comers clat- tered in, took off their boots, genuflected to- waids Mecca, and at once took their part in the simple service. The congregation pros- trated itself to the ground, rose to its feet, and then, tailor-fashion, sat on its heels to listen to the exhortation. This was in praise lof the Sultan of Turkey as Sheikh-ul-Islam, and his four caliphs, and again the adorationa were made. :

When the short service was over the wor- shippers rose to their feet, clasped each other in boisterous embraces, and at once filled the room with the beatific smoke of cigarettes. For thirty days they had been' denied the comforts of food, drink, and tobacco during the hours of alleged London sunshine. Freed from this disability their first craving was for tobacco. It is the same through all the world of Islam, as witness a story recently told by adevout Moslem: "You should see my old father, who lives in Constantinople. Five minutes before the sunset gun fires on Top- liané he takes out his pouch and rolls a cigarette. Still engaged in contemplation of Allah he holds the cigarette in one hand and a match in the other. Bang goesthe gun, and at once the room is filled with clouds of smoke. Three cigarettes smoked at steam-engine rate, and then my father goes to breakfast !"

div.head:
NATIVE OPINION.
MUDIRS AND INSPECTORS.
div.p: (From "At Watan")

It appears that the whole Egyptian Press is of one mind upon the question of these youthful Inspectors entrusted by the Ministry of Interior with the serious work of saperintending the work of its officials in the provinces. The belief in their approaching doom is also aniversal as far as we can see, but it is idle to deny that the prospect of strengthening the hands of our Mudirs and Mamoors has been viewed with mingled feelings among the various sections of the community. To the ordinary Effendi or Bey in Cairo and other cities the projected change io the present order of things is equitable; the native go- vernor ought to be respected and given some power in his sphere. Bat to the fellah, of these provinces the change ie most undesirable and may be considered as de- trimental to the interests of the lower clas- ses at large. The fellah has tried the English Inspector and found him wanting in experience and dourtesy, easy to misguide and everbearing to a degree ; but the fellah has never been robbed of his property by an Inspector, nor flogged, nor sent to prison without cause. The English Inspector was neither brilliant or oblig- ing, but he was not cruel or anjast. As to the Madir or Mamoor the experience of the fellah has shewn different results. The ordinary Egyp- tian prefers anything to the absolute rule ofa native Mamoor. He accuses him of injastice for personal motives and insists apon applying for an inquiry into his case by an English Ins- pector whenever he falls into trouble with a person of the official class. To remove the Ins- pector altogether is, therefore, to abolish one of the main securities of justice and good government in the country.

The question is, therefore, two sided. We approve the idea of giving more authority to the governors but we have reasons to fear the consequences of such & reversion to an old and discredited system. We do not like the present inspector with his supercilious manners and mischievous inexperience, but we really want bim and do not feel at ease withoat him. In other words the inspector is necessary but he ought to be of a different type, passessing more tact and more experience than the young man of the present regime. This being the case, we can find only one solution acceptable to all parties by maintaining the post of inspec- tor but appointing to it men to whom our Mudirs will submit with pleasure and who can bring experience and prestige to help them in their work of inspection. We need not have too many of them. Only one superior: official of this class for Upper Egypt and one for Lower Egypt will inspire the people with confidence and suffice to check the tendencies of erratic Mamoors. If we were to name the persons best qualified in our opinion for such. high and onerous duties we would mention Coles Pasha and Harvey Pasha to divide the country be- tween them and put our internal affairs on a sound basis. Svch an arrangement woald be acceptable to all parties and gratifying to the nation at large. We call the attention of authorities to it and trast that it will be given fall consideration.

div.head: BRITISH FLEET AT MALTA.
div.p: Admiral Sir Charles Drury and Lady Drury gave a dinner last week, at Malta, in honour of the Ottoman Consul-General and Mme. Azarian. Most of the officers who were presented to 'the Sultan during the British fleet's recent visit to Constantinople were present, in tull uniform, and wearing the decorations be- stowed upon them by the Sultan. Lady Drary wore the Grand Cordon of the Chefakat Order, and the Commander-in-Chief the Grand Cordon of the Osmanieh. Sir Charles Drury, in pro- ff posing the toast of the Sultan, referred to the brilliant reception accorded to himself and Lady Drury and the British officers on the dccasion of their visit to Constantinople. At the conclusion of the Admiral's speech,. the band played the Hamidieh March. The Turkish Consul-General, in reply, thanked the Admiral, and said that his Sovereign greatly welcomed valorous men of all lands, and particularly those belonging to the great British nation, to whom Turkey had been bound by a friendship of a century's standing. Azarian Effendi, in conclusion, drank to the health of their Majesties and of the Royal Family, to Sir Charles and Lady Drury, and to the health snd prosperity of the British Navy.

div.head: A NEW DISCOVERY OF LOST CLASSIC LITERATURE IN EGYPT.
div.p: Early in the year 411 B.C. the democratic constitution at Athens was and the sovereignty of the people passed into the hands of a Council of Four Hundred.

This "Coup d'Etat" was rendered possible by the political follies of the demagoguee who had been unwisely elected by the populace, cul- minating in the disastrous Sicilian expedition, being feebly sustained with insufficient funds.

The Council of the Four Hundred did not however long remain in power, their ignorance of administration and aflairs and the disor- ganised state of the finances, and exhaustion of both 'army and navy made it impossible tor them to improve the situation, and in a few months swept away and the de- mocratic tution restored to the city.

One of the most marked members of the ved council was Antiphon who came Anh and who had not originally adopt- Oratory and composed speeches and pleadings For speakers and advocates. He came from his home at, apparently, what he considered a crisis in the history of his state, entered heartily into the plot which subjected the oligarchy of 400 for the larger democracy. The former as soon as in power became divided into two parties the Moderates, and the [ntran- sigents, and Antiphon became an important member of the extremist section if not its real leader. Finding their position becoming more insecure, the Oligarchy,to enable themselves to have a free hand to combat the democracy, decided to treat with the Lacedemonias and sent Antiphon and 11 other delegates to Sparta.

Shortly after the return of the plenipoten- tiaries the four hundred were overturned and many of them exiled, or fled. Antiphon re- mained. He was, however, soon charged with treason, the crime being having been a mem- ber of the embassy to Sparta, but at his trial the additional count was made of having helped to destroy the constitution.
The speech which he delivered in his own defence Thucydides tells us "was the finest ever pronounced." It did not, however, prevent his condemnation to death.

The admiration expressed by Thucydides was repeated by other classic authors, and still more effectively as proof of its truth by subse- quent orators who imitated and probably also copied from it in addresses for others when arraigned for alleged political misdemeanours.

It may be therefore that if we could detect such plagiarisms or similarities, we could 'res- tore much of the famous speech, but practically it has hitherto been completely lost except for a few citations by grammarians and lexico- Graphers.

To-day however the long wished for event of the recovery of this celebrated specimen of the forensic oratory, and the logic and argnu- ments of the master of the Greek language and forms of thought ; has come to pass, and Egypt is again the treasure house wherein has been stored, and now restored, to us this precious fragmerit of ancient literature, for as we shall see we have not now a complete edition of Antiphon's speech but only a considerable portion thereof.

Last winter M. Jules Nicolle of Geneva, who had some years ago acquired for the Museum of that city a most valuable collection. of Egyptian papyri, visited Egypt again with the object of obtaining a further number of mabuscripts, and there among a quantity which he purchased were four portions of the apology of Antiphon; originally elegantly written "upon beautiful paper, evidently an exemplar de luxe".

The texts upon the four parts preserved are of unequal length and appareatly separated a good deal from each other. Thus several columns of writing are evidently from the argument whilst others appertained to the exposition of facts, and some to the perora- tion This accidental arrangement of the newly found fragment is happily however rather advantageous. The fourfold extracts present a better view of the general plan of the discourse than a continuous piece of equal length would have done.

We can now follow not only the system upon which Antiphon founded his defence, but also the role which he explains he followed as chief of his party, and also as an improvised adminis- trator in the great crisis in which he became involved. We see him suddenly taking the offensive against his accusers, and then when, according to custom, the moment had arrived to appeal to the compassion of his judges, he alludes to his family, his children and grand- children as interceding tor him.
Historically also the allusions iv his argu- ment are most Valuable. The illustrious names of principle parties to the revolution appear such as Pisander, Phrynichus, and Theramenes.

The most lengthy fragment fortunately dis- closes to us the position thought best for taking up by an Athenian orator and, perliaps, immature statesman in face of a terrible accusation levelled against himself. He not only denies participating in the overthrow of the democracy but says he never dreamt of it. What then made him join the oligarchy ? He alleges the force of circumstances saying they only had determined Bis conduct.
He endeavours to prove his only leader was patriotism, never ambition, and still less private interest.

Had he consulted the last no one would bave more ardently maintained the democratic constitution. It is evident that it was the -foree and eloquence with which he developes this part of his apology that caused later speakers in similar critical circamétances, to envy his great effort and his words. It is probable Antiphon had but the morroy of his indictment in which to prepare his defence, moreover the accusation, as stated, was amended by the addition, and he had in his speech to reply on the spur of the moment to the attack of his foes ot whose line of address he had no previous warning. Also he needed to suit his words to the audience and consequently doubtless changed in his speech, the form he had. previously selected for many parts of it.

The literary perfection of the speech seems to show that between the vocal deliverance of it and the condemnation ; and the execution of his sentence, he was able to work at the matter so as to prepare it for publication. Before he drank the deadly draaght, his last moments may have been occupied in editing these lines, which now after the lapse of centuries can be perused once again. The very thought of such a thing makes it impossible to read without emotion these sentences composed so along ago and returned to mankind, let us hope, not only to never be lost again but to be augmented and perhaps completed, by the finding of another copy of what may thus correctly be rallied the immortal Apology of Antiphon.
Joseph Offord.

div.head: EGYPT" AND BABYLONIA COMPARED.
div.p: The last lecture of the course on the com- parison of Egypt and Babylonia was given by Professor Flinders Petrie at University College last Thureday. The poetic oracles in parallel verses, and with repetition of a refrain as in the Psalms, were compared with the long poem with refrains in honour of Senusert in Egypt. Probably both have their source in the Orien- tal custom of one inventive man starting a series of imprompta lines, between each of which the rest of a working groap shout out a fixed refrain. This is commonly done while en- gaged in united work like~baaling, and a si- milar form may well have been used in reli- gious meetings, which are now confined to mere repetition, as in the zikrs.

The ,penitential psalms of Babyloni similar'to the Hebrew Psalms, find no para aI in Egypt, where introspection and self-accusa- tion were as little known as in ancient Greece. The prayer of Ashur Canipal and the Divine answer is hardly treated so finely as the battle prayer of Rameses and its answer. The custom of writing curses was usual in Baby- lonia as in Greece, but such are rare in Egypt, and only belong to the age of the Shihaks under Mesopotamian influence. The impor- tant literatare of the cosmogony, so similar to Genesis, is entirely different in Egypt, and this shows that the two stocks of population were entirely distinct, as the fundamental ideas of the how and why of things are most unalterable.

Lastly, the interesting class of letters was touched on ; such are far commoner in Baby- lonia than in Egypt, and the perishable natare of papyrus compared with clay tablets accounts for the difference. The comparison of the two civilizations is of great value for showing the strong points of each in which they excel, works of imagination and character in Egypt, documents and records in Babylonia.

div.head: NEXT YEAR'S BUDGET.
div.p: To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,-Out of the multitudinal rumours with which Cairo 'is filled regariling the probable effect of the 1908 badget upon the. varions administrations in Egypt, the one which states that there will be a more or less general reduc. tion in the number of officials would appear to be the most probable, for the fact is already Ae- sured that the number in the Tanzim ia to be reduced and there is no reason to suppose that this will be by any means an isolated instance, for the Tanzim, more especially the Towns and Buildings department, which happens to be the particular one threatened, is necessarily ja most important one, and one which is bound to inerease in size and in importance as the country still further developes. The budget is yearly & source of great interest, and this year it is particularly so, as there has been so much speculation on the matter of the reductions of the various staffs that no particular depart ment feels safe for the future. Freom a super ficial standpoint it would saturrally appear to the outsider that the despartment under whose jurisdiection the streets of Cairo fall would be one which might be reduced with the 'least harmful results since it makes no tiiagible use of the money which is yearly allotted to them, and on the principle that things could not be worse than they are at present, it would certain- ly seem that this money being for the moat part simply wasted through bed management, no good result would accrue were it incréased a thousand fold.

But if this is the case with this particular department it is far from being so with the majority of the others, and it is "a matter for sincere regret that the existing state ot finan- ces will in all probabity not permit of the hoped for increases in the pay of the Native staff in many of the hard working and res- ponsible branches of the Government admi- nistration, it will be generally admitted . for instance that the Telegraph service is none too highly paid considering the responsibility undertaken and the skill required by: . its officials. Rents have been a very-serious con- sideration for a long time past but it ionly recently that food has taken such a sudden rise in price and increased the difficulties of living to an @xtraordinary height, and if the advances in rent and living which at présent obtain are sustained it will become almest an impossibiljty to exist in the town on salaries which were formerly more that sufficient.

It would be greatly to the. benefit of both the Government and its employes if the former would take the question of the housing of its minor officials immediately in hand and build them dwelling places in Cairo which could be advantageously let at reasonable prices, the in- vestment conld not fail to be to the advantage to the Government. whileit would once and for all settle the burning question of rents, and, obviate themecessity of calling for continual drains from the Government, who increase the salaries of its officials only to fill the pockets of individual speculators who were fortunate enough to secure land in the haleyon days, which are now, we may say fortunately for Cairo, over.

I have no wish for speenlation, as specula- tion, on the part of the Government, but in a case such a this where the interests of the vast number of its servants are in question, then it becomes a necessity for some step to be taken in order to relieve the depression cansed by the enofmous rentals demanded by private property owners.
Yours truly

div.head: SPORT AT PORT SAID
div.p: Yesterday afteroooh the Port Said Inter- national Sporting Cleb indulged in a little hockey pracfice. 'There was a good attendance of last year's players and several new hands were also noticed. Among the latter was E. Cassar who played a very hard game. This year's hockey team shoold prove themselves equal to any team which is likely to visit us during the season. The most conspicuous players this afternoon were Messrs. J. Chesman, ©. Broatch, Ingram and Cassar.

Oar Association Football XI should also prove stronger than last year. Judging from last week's practice, and if the team would anly do a little more training, they should have a very successful season.

div.head:
THE MAGIC OF THE SPADE.
EGYPT AND WESTERN ASIA.
div.p: By W. Sr. Cuap Boscawen.

The activity in Oriental exploration during recent years has been snch that the time 'has come for a gegeral summary of results to be made. The important discoveries in Egypt, especially in the reali of prehistoric:and 'earty dynastic times, has added new and important chapters to the history of Egypt, while in Western Asia the work of the Amertean, French, and others in Chaldea and Swsianoria have produced such results as to completely revolutionise all previous conclusions. " 'The great work of Professor Maspero on the "Anvient History of the Peoples of the Rast," painstaking as it was, is flow archaic, and the Christian Knowledge Soviety, ~who' pu- blished it, have done well in entrustitig the compilation of a new and comptehehsive 'work on the subject to Mr. L. W! Ring and Mr. H. R: 'Hall, of the British Museum. In this new work, "Egypt and Western Asia in the Light of Recent Discovery," we have the latest results of research from the Hants of "expert authorities.

Egyptian and Caneifotm scholars," but have each carried ont extensive explorations, and each has a thorough ktiowledge ofthe countries which have been the seats of great civilisations. Mr. Ha!l's account of prehistoric Egypt is excellent. His deseription of the early races of the Nile Valley is free from the rash dog- matism which characterised the work of so many previous writers. It is marked by a clear statement of the tacts, and then followed by a clear summarisation of results. His account of the incoming of Asiatic influences is certainly new and important, and his sug- gestion that the custom of dull length berial and mummification was derived from Baby- lonia is most striking. He compares the burial scenes on the "Shell of the Vultures," and his arguments are most convincing. It is the burial customs of the ancient Egyptians that tell us most of their early story, and these he describes very clearly. He notes every impor- tant discovery, describes its value, and assigns it to its proper place in history, and it will be along time before his work will need revi sion. The account of the discoveries at Deir el Bahari, and of the royal tombs at 'hebes is most clear, coming from one who had taken part ifi the explorations, or was on the spot at the time when the diseoveries were made. His remarks on the hoenter, 'King Khu-en-Aten or Amenophis IV. will be of especial value at the present time, when so much controversy is being carried on regarding the body found in the supposed tomb of Queen Tie.
In dealing with the recent discoveries in Western Asia Mr. King has a far darger field to cover, but he brings to his work a specialist's knowledge which Professor Maspero did not possess.

The important discoveries daring recent years in Babylon, Assyria, Asia Minor, Armenia, Xc., are described as the reconstruc- tion of the history of Western Asia, is ac- complished in a manner which will astonish many who have hitherto bad no idea of the perfect articulation there is between the varions histories of the nations of the ancient East. For the first time the anthor sets before usa: cleaft picture of the ancient Sumerian civilisation. He shows from the inscriptions from Tel-lo, and especially from the long text of the cylinders of Gudea, how perfect it was in its patriarchal simplicity. Its indigenous character is now beyond doubt, and there is revealed to us apatient plodding and highly inventive people, who have just claim to be regarded as the founders of the world's civilisa- tion. They were not aggresive, making but few conquests, contenting themselves with holding their own against their neighbours, and especially their hereditary foe the ElaVites. To this wonderful people we must look for the invention of writing, of mathematics, geometery, agriculture, anfl most ofthe elements of calture.

With the advent of the Semites, a great change took place ; and certainly for the good of humanity in general. With that wotderfol, adaptive faculty which charactherises 'the Semite, we find them borrowing from the Su- meriens their writing, social laws, mathemAatios, especially in relation to trade. It is the'old story, so often repeated, of the physically stronger being conquered intellectually by the weaker. 'The most important and fat-reaching result which Mr. King pots most clearly before us was the propagation of this acquired calture hy the Semites. The energetic Semite soon brought it under his rule By conquest and peaceful commerce, he spread the Babylonian language and laws from the 'Tigris to thehanks of the Halyo. Semitic Babylonian became the French of the ancient East, the language of diplomacy and commerce.

This portion of the book; will add Anuch to Mr. King's reputation. It does not weary the reader with a long-verbatim translation of the code of Khammurabi, but gives a concise précis of the-laws, 'illdstrdted from contem- porary documents. The account which he gives of the Trans-Tigris civilisations of Elam and the Kaswites give us the first study of the restiits' of M. de Morgéh's work at Sosa, and shows low mach has been done and how mueh may yet be accomplished, when farther ex- dre made in Khoristan. This region now falls' within 'the sphere of British influence in Pétsia, arid pertiaps Biglish explorers may yet have a'chianes. The' whole work is full of tiew tiatérin! pleasantly set before' the-reacer. The illa#tratiors ate Humerous and excellent, but why no niap ? It is a work which no stu- dent should be"without.

div.head: A BRITISH SCHOOL CONSTANTINOPLE.
div.p: Comthentitig-on the letter from Sir Adam Block tothé "Times," whieh we-reprodaeced in a Técént fase, ré theestabhishment of « British school'atOonstentinople the same paper says : —

Speaking on bebalf of an infleential British Committee; whith incltdes officials of the Em- band y' arid: Goriswlate'and besiness men, he (Sir Ada: Blook) pleads for hetp. for the recently- founded soliook for English boys in Constanti- nople. We lave great tradeinterests in Turkey That' they are not 'greater than they are, and that'they are not expanding as rapidly as the imtetests of other nations, is largely dne to the deplorable warit of practical 'education among the Englismen who go there, and among their children. In no place in-the-world is that grave fault of the English character; the unwilling- ness to'take' trauble in-edaecating oneself, more cohspicaous than in Tarkey. To a young Ger- man, & Frenchman, or a Greek, it is a compel- ling and instinctive prineiple that the foanda- tion of success in business is a knowledge of certain necessary things, the first being the langaage of the people with whom he has to trade. Among the English trading classes, at home and abroad, such a belief is rare. The contrast is reflested in'w most painful way in the action of the different Governments with regard to their subjects in Turkey. As Sir Adam Block points out, France spends £12,000 a year on French sebools in Turkey ; Germany, which - assigns £89,500 a year to: German schools abroad, gives £1,000 of this to its schoo! at Constantmople; and Italy, Austria, and Rassia' also 'subsidize their schools in the Turkish Empire. What does England do! [n | reply to astrong memorial to the Treasury, fron the Eaglishmen who are reponsible for the new school, the Treasary refused all help, on the ground that there was 'no precedent." We really thought that the days of that old phrase were long smce numbered. If, however, it is to be used again, we would remark that there is no precedent for the acuteness of foreign competition which now exists at Constantinople as'elsewhere ; and that there was no precedent for the very meritorious action of the present Government, when, in conjunc- tion with France, it supported the co-operation of the Bank of England with French capitalists in purchasing the quays at Constantinople one of the most important measares taken for asserting the community of Anglo-French com- mercial interests in the Near East. Sir Edward Grey, indeed, has shown himself very creditably alive to the importance of developing oar trade with Turkey ; and that matter of the quays, together with his successful pressure for the extension of the Smyrnha-Aidin railway and of steamer facilities on the Tigris, is a happy proof of what may be done. We cannot help thinking that, if he seriously considered the case of this school at Constantinople, he would induce the Treasury to make the prece dent 'that 'they have 'sought for in vain. It' seems to be impossible to make the s¢hool self-supporting ; but then education is never self-supporting, Our primary schools are paid tor by grants and rates, and neither Eton and Harrow nor Oxford and Cambridge could do the work they do if it were not for their endowments. Here at 'least are "prece dents" for the Treasury. The sun thatit is asked to sapply is 'very' swall—too small, we we should Love thought. If Germany finds £1,000 a year for its boys and girls at Constanti- nople, England might surely find the same. However, ifSir Adam Block's Committee are satisfied for the present with £200, that sum daght to be te ly given, if only to prevent the Bnaglet children at Constantinople from becoming Levantines, with no national edneation and the proper sense of the country from which they spring. If this is done, there may ultimately be some. hope that, when a roam Englishman at Constantinople offers imself for a post, it will not be found neces sary, as Sir Adam Block, with his experience as head of a great-revenue administration, tells ns is very often the case at present, to pass him over beeause his German or Greek coin- petitor is much better educated and conse quently much more efficient.

div.head:
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES BT CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Vendredi 15 Novembre
Le taux de l'escompte libre 4 Londres est renseigné invarié 4 6 3/4 pour cent.

Au Stock-Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a perdu 1/8 4 82 1/8, L'Unifiée s'est maintenue & 99. La National Bank a réactionné de 3/8 a 20 1/4. L'Agricole a été soutenue a 8, la Daira 4 12 1/2 et la Delta Light 4 9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu 1 franc 4 682. La Banque d'Athénes a gagné 1 franc 4 108. Les Lots Turcs sont restés in- changés 4 164.
Décidément la question des dossiers & liqui der arrive A |'ordre du jour. Ce ne serait qu'un juste retour des choses diici-bas, et tel serait pris qui croyait prendre.
D'une lettre que nous recevons A ce sujet, nous détachons les lignes suivantes :

"(est un fait bien avéré qu'un trop grand nombre de maisons ne possédent plus, ily a beau jour, si elle la possédérent jamais, |'in tégralité des titres qu'elles devaient acheter poar tels et tels de leurs-clients.

"Elles continvent, /toutefois, A attribuer 4 chacun ce qui lui revjent, gravement, dans des relevés mensuels de comptes, en omettant une seule petite chose, les numéros des titres. Ces maisons ont tout bonnement venduan temps chand, a leur plus grand profit, sans cure ni souci du client, la plapart des titres, en con- servant simplement quelques-uns qui passent du dossier client A au dossier client B pour aller un autre jour au dossier client C, snivant les circonstances qu'elles eréent ou font créer, pour exécuter l'un ou l'autre de leurs bons clients — gent taillable 4 merci — au moment propice pour les liquidateurs.

"Ces reliefs de dossiers réunis en un seul, ambulant, me font l'effet dela bonne 4 tout faire d'un ménage modeste, ou mieux encore Veffet des dix figurantsd'ane troupe de comédie en disette de personnel, qui entrant par une porte, sortant par une autre pour rentrer par la premiére, ressortir par la deuxiéme, ete. . . représentent sur la scéne, 4 eux dix, toute une foule endélireou toute une armée triomphante.

"Tl fant arréter de tels abus, facteurs de la crisé actuelle. Un premier moyen trés simple —— que tous les clients réclament impérative- ment 4 leurs dépositaires quels qu'ils soient, les bordereanx détaillés des titres leur appar tenant en exigeant les numéros de ces titres.— Préciser la propriété c'est souvent |'assurer.....'

Ici, notre marché de plus en plus dirigé par les tendances que manifeste le marché anglais sur les valeurs égyptiennes, a été aujourd'bui légérement plus faible qu'hier va le recul de la National Bank & Londres et les quelques réa- lisations que la reprise de ces deux derniers jours devait forcément provoquer.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na- tional Bank se tasse 4 20 3/8-7/16. L'Agri- cole recule 4 7 7/8-19/16 et la Banque d'A- thénes & 112.

Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire perdent 3 francs 4165. La Daira Sanieh rétrograde a 129/16 et le Crédit Foncier Egyptien 4 678, sa part de fondateur est en hausse 4715 et ses obligations anciennes et nouvelles s'inscri- vent 4 292 et 253 ex-droit au tirage. La privi- légiée Béhéra est ramenée a 4 1/16. Les Allot- ments sont en reprise 4 P T. 50.La Compagnie Immobilitre baisse 4 280-285 alors que sa part gagne 5francs 4 295.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, calme complet, sanf un tassement de 3/16 sur les Baehler a 5.
Parmi les petites valeurs, Jes Markets s'a- lourdissent 4 25/6-25/9. Les fondateurs Estates haussent 4 2 7/8-3 et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail revient & 20/3.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, les passages suivants :

"Malgré la crise américaine et les difficultés monétaires et boursiéres qu'elle a suscitées notre merché a témoigné d'un ressort extraor- dinaire et si la repercussion de tous ces événe- ments a provoqué une baisse générale, elle a été du moins raisonnable.

"C'est moins la crise américaine que la hausse successive du taux de la Banque d'An- gleterre qui a amené la chite de nos Consolidés et la dépression simultanée des titres les plus en faveur. Un revirement s'est produit cepen- dant dés qu'il fut certain que la Banque de France viendrait 'A notre aide, et si la gréve des chemins de fer n'avait été encore mena- gante, la cote aurait présenté une reprise sé- rieuse. Néanmoinson sent venir ane amélio- ration 4 plusieurs indices, l'Amérique envoyant des nouvelles beaucoup plus favorables et le découvert qui a passablement 'travaillé tous ces temps-ci devant bien finir par se racheter.

"Les valeurs égyptiennes n'ont pas échappé 4 l'ambiance générale et malgré la confiance que professionnels et capitalistes leur conser- vent, elles ont rétrogradé come les autres, wn peu plus 4 de certains moments, car les ordres d'Egypte étaient trés nombreux et le découvert en a profité trés largement.

"Quant a la situation monétaire, on ne peut faire encore aucun pronostic, vu la tin de l'an née trés proche et les besoins monétaires ton- jours trés grands acette époque. On compte néanmoins sur une légére amélioration."
